channel.title: Jordan Ristow
channel.description: The interwebs home of Jordan Ristow

item.title: Daily Algorithm Practice - Merge Sorted Lists
item.description: Problem StatementGiven two sorted number arrays, nums1 and nums2, merge nums2 into nums1 as one sorted array.We are given m and n which…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement

Given two sorted number arrays, nums1 and nums2, merge nums2 into nums1 as one sorted array.

We are given m and n which represent the initialized elements in nums1 and nums2 respectively. We may assume that nums1 was initialized with enough space to fit all values from nums2.

Example input:

  • nums1 = [1,2,3,0,0,0] m = 3
  • nums2 = [2,5,6] n = 3

Description of Algorithm

One method of doing this is to brute force our way through the arrays. The pseudocode would look like:

  • Look at first item in nums1
  • compare to first item in nums2
  • if smaller, go to next item in nums1
  • if larger, move nums1 item one to the right, insert nums2 item one.

This would progress through each item in each list until they are all in place. This is extremely inefficient however.

A better algorithm would use the fact that they are already sorted smallest to largest and that we know the total length nums1 will be after merging, m+n. With this, we can start at the end of both lists, comparing values and replacing values as we go. Pseudocode:

  • Look at last sorted element in nums1
  • compare to last element in nums2
  • if larger, move to end of nums1 array
  • if smaller, remove nums2 element and place in last spot of nums1
  • decrease size of m and n

Algorithm in Code

def merge(self, nums1: List[int], m: int, nums2: List[int], n: int) -> None:
    if nums2:
        while nums2:
            if m>0 and nums1[m-1] > nums2[n-1]:
                nums1[m+n-1] = nums1[m-1]
                m -= 1
            else:
                nums1[m+n-1] = nums2.pop()
                n -= 1

Code Walkthrough

Diving into our algorithm line by line (skipping the function definition) we have:

if nums2:

Here we are checking to make sure there is an initial value in nums2.

while nums2:

This sets up our iterative loop that lasts as long as there is a value left in nums2.

if m>0 and nums1[m-1] > nums2[n-1]:
    nums1[m+n-1] = nums1[m-1]
    m -= 1

This portion checks to make sure m is greater than zero and compares the last sorted value in nums1 to the final value in nums2. If the final sorted value of nums1 is larger than the final value in nums2, we know that that value is the largest value in the final array. So we move that value to the end of nums1 and leave the final value of nums2 in place. Finally we decrement m by 1.

else:
    nums1[m+n-1] = nums2.pop()
    n -= 1

This branch of our if-else statement means the last value of nums2 is larger than the last sorted value of nums1, which means it is the largest value of our final sorted array. So we pop it off nums2 and assign it to the final position in nums1. We then decrement n by 1.

This will continue looping until we pop off the final value of nums2.

Conclusion

This algorithm is a great example of how we can leverage some of the extra knowledge we may have about a problem to come up with a more efficient solution to algorithm problems. In this case, we knew that each array was already sorted and that the first array had zeroes for the last n elements.

Thanks for following along. Please reach out to me via social with any questions or comments.

item.title: Building a React Based Portfolio Index Site
item.description: After playing around with Gatsby.js to rebuild my web presence, I started looking more into the JAMstack idea/community and I realized I…
item.content:encoded:
After playing around with Gatsby.js to rebuild my web presence, I started looking more into the JAMstack idea/community and I realized I needed to brush up and practice on my React/JavaScript site generation knowledge. With that I mind, I am setting out to convert a basic html generated portfolio site to one built with react components. Follow along with this series. This site will be styled using Materialize.css. You can view what the final product we are building towards looks like here. The code repo can be found on GitHub here. Head on over to the repo and open up the index.html file in your favorite code editor to begin.

Part One: Setting up a common header

When we look at the overall layout of the page, we can see where certain parts of the page would be repeated across any other pages of this site. The easiest one is the header part. Instead of repeating ourselves by putting the raw header code in every page of this website, why don’t we build out a header component that can be imported into any other page we build?

Converting from HTML to JavaScript

It is very easy to take traditional HTML elements and put them into a React component. See the code sample below for the whole picture and then we will go through it line by line to see what is going on.

import React from "react"
import "./materialize.css"
const Header = () => (
<nav>
<div className="nav-wrapper grey darken-1">
<a href="#" className="brand-logo">
 Just A Sample
</a>
<ul id="nav-mobile" className="right hide-on-med-and-down">
<li>
<a href="#">Website</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="#">Layout</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="#">Yasss</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</nav>
)
export default Header
view raw portfolioHeader.js hosted with ❤ by GitHub

Diving into each piece of code

import React from "react";
import "./materialize.css"
view raw importLines.js hosted with ❤ by GitHub
These two lines pull in React and our materialize stylesheet from their respective locations (note: this write up is using react within Gatsby.js, the import statements may look different if you are using a different framework.).

const Header () => (
// Content of header goes here
)
view raw headerWrapper.js hosted with ❤ by GitHub
This is where we define our Header, with the styling elements we want to include defined inside of it.

<nav>
<div className="nav-wrapper grey darken-1">
<a href="#" className="brand-logo">
 Just A Sample
</a>
<ul id="nav-mobile" className="right hide-on-med-and-down">
<li>
<a href="#">Website</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="#">Layout</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="#">Yasss</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
</nav>
view raw headerContent.js hosted with ❤ by GitHub
This is the structure of our header, notice how each element uses className instead of class to define the styling rules that are to be applied to it.

export default Header
view raw export.js hosted with ❤ by GitHub
Finally, we are exporting the Header component so it can be imported into other components or pages.

Conclusion

This was just a very basic walk through on converting a site from basic HTML to a page generated via React JavaScript components. There is a lot more capability from React we can incorporate and I may dive into that later on. But from this, you can start to see how we would extrapolate this out across an entire web site/application.

item.title: Daily Algorithm Work May 23, 2019
item.description: Problem Statement:Consider all the leaves of a binary tree. From left to right order, the values of those leaves form a leaf value sequence…
item.content:encoded:
Problem Statement:

Consider all the leaves of a binary tree. From left to right order, the values of those leaves form a leaf value sequence.

For example, in the given tree above, the leaf value sequence is (6, 7, 4, 9, 8).

Two binary trees are considered leaf-similar if their leaf value sequence is the same.

Return true if and only if the two given trees with head nodes root1 and root2 are leaf-similar.

Solution Description:

This problem is a variation of a depth first search problem. In this implementation of DFS, we need to build out our list of leaf nodes for each root node and then compare these lists to see if they are equivalent. The code implementation of this is below (language used is Python).

def leafSimilar(root1, root2):
        def dfs(node):
            if node:
                if not node.left and not node.right:
                    yield node.val
                yield from dfs(node.left)
                yield from dfs(node.right)

        return list(dfs(root1)) == list(dfs(root2))

Above we have the implementation, now let’s walk through it to look under the hood a little. We will skip over the def lines and jump straight into the good parts.

 if not node.left and not node.right:
     yield node.val

This chunk is our base case test: if there is a value in either node.left or node.right, this node is not a leaf. If there are no values in either node.left or node.right, we yield the value of the node. Note the use of yield here instead of return, this allows us to pass a value while still maintaining state.

yield from dfs(node.left)
yield from dfs(node.right)

This chunk is the heart of our recursive call. The first line passes the left child of the node into our depth first search function while the second line passes the right child. 

  return list(dfs(root1)) == list(dfs(root2))

This is the final line, where we call our dfs function with our two root values. Wrapping the dfs function in the list method allows us to build out a list of all the leaf nodes that are yielded from our function (the main reason we used yield instead of return in our function). Once both lists have been built, we check if they are equivalent, finally returning True or False based on that check.

item.title: Missing Places
item.description: As I was sitting in a hip taco spot in downtown Boise this past weekend, I started reflecting on what this city means to me. Growing up, I…
item.content:encoded:
As I was sitting in a hip taco spot in downtown Boise this past weekend, I started reflecting on what this city means to me. Growing up, I never really had a hometown, bouncing from city to city, state to state and even country to country meant nowhere gave me that feeling of “home”. Until I moved to Boise for my undergrad.

A few years ago, after spending 10 years here, I moved away for a new job opportunity. For the first year, I had this hole in me, which I attributed to just missing the city of Boise and not settling in to my new location. As time went on, I still felt that hole. It got to a point where I realized it wasn’t just missing the city. There was a feeling my memories of Boise brought up that had nothing to do with a specific location.

The more I thought about it, I realized it wasn’t just the city itself. It was the community of people I was able to build while living there. Between friends from my undergrad days, people I met at crossfit and colleagues who became friends, I had an amazing community of people that really made my time in Boise feel like home.

Our brains are incredibly powerful. This feeling that is associated to a place affects how I picture the city when I think about it. As time has passed, the people who made up that community have moved on with their lives, taking them out of the city. Physically, the city itself has changed with a lot of development happening while I’ve been away. These two factors combine together so every time I come back it feels less and less like the place I remember. More often, I find myself wondering if this is still the same city I originally fell in love with.

What is the place that gives you that feeling of home? Do you find it being more related to the people you have there or the actual physical space?

item.title: Who is Jordan Ristow?
item.description: Allow me to reintroduce myself…Since I’ve revamped my site, I figured it would be a good idea to provide a bit more detail on who I am and…
item.content:encoded:
Allow me to reintroduce myself…

Since I’ve revamped my site, I figured it would be a good idea to provide a bit more detail on who I am and what my story is (so far). Especially since right now the site is more focused on blogging than being my online portfolio.

Just the highlights

Hi, I’m Jordan! After being miserable with my life, I recently made a huge leap of faith, quit my old job, sold all of my belongings and moved to Austin Texas. I realized I needed focus on what would make me happy instead of worrying about other peoples expectations of me. So here I am, reinventing myself and enjoying life again. This blog is going to be my attempt at documenting my transition as well as an avenue to explore three of my favorite topics: software engineering, personal finance and philsophy/psychology. Please tag along with me and reach out/connect with me if anything resonates with you.

Summary of Expertise:

Education Background
  • BS in Materials Science and Engineering - Boise State University 12

  • MS in Software Development - Maryville University 18

    Professional Background
  • Charles Schwab, Associate Software Engineer June 2019 -
  • United States Air Force, Operations Engineering Manager December 2016 - May 2019
  • United States Air Force, Lead Project Manager August 2014 - December 2016
  • United States Air Force, Mechanical Engineer August 2013 - July 2014

  • United States Air Force, Junior Engineer July 2012 - July 2013

    Technical Capabilities

  • Python

    • Proficient with full stack development using Flask
    • Object Oriented Programming with Python
    • Experience with SciPy/NumPy and other data science libraries in Python
    • Sample website built with flask

  • Database Technologies

    • Experience with various SQL based databases (Postgres, MySQL, MicrosoftSQL)
    • Experience with MongoDB NoSQL databases

  • JavaScript

    • Experience working with various JavaScript libraries
    • React
    • Node.js
    • D3.js

  • Java

    • Understanding of Java OOP concepts

item.title: First Reaction to Using Gatsby.js
item.description: Using Gatsby.js is Easy and PowerfulSo, after running through most of the tutorial on gatsby, I wanted to do a quick write up on my overall…
item.content:encoded:
Using Gatsby.js is Easy and Powerful

So, after running through most of the tutorial on gatsby, I wanted to do a quick write up on my overall impressions.

I haven’t played around with too many other static site generators, but I have really enjoyed the developer experience gatsby provides. I have wanted to work with both React and GraphQL and this gave me the perfect use case.

Getting started was incredibly easy as well. I built a new project with one of their simple starters and had it up and running on my GitHub page with ease. It took me a little bit of time playing around with different components to get the basic look and content the way I wanted, but deploying it was a breeze with the gh-pages plugin.

As I customize and build out new parts of my site, I plan on writing up the process and how I did it. But for now, I wanted to throw up some quick impressions.

item.title: New Website/Blog
item.description: We’re BAAAAAACK!!!!Well, I spent most of this weekend messing around with gatsby.js to build up this new blog/website. I finally got most of…
item.content:encoded:
We’re BAAAAAACK!!!!

Well, I spent most of this weekend messing around with gatsby.js to build up this new blog/website. I finally got most of it sorted out and got this barebones blog up and running.

Over the next few weeks I plan on building out a few more pages focused on who I am, what I do and showing some examples of my work. Kind of like an online resume. During all of this, I will do a more detailed write up of my experience working with gatsby.js.

After that, I plan on posting more blog items focused on philosophy and personal finances.

Thanks for hanging around with me!
